title: 112_s1921
content: The "Reducing Energy Use Through Retrofitting Older Vehicles Act" or the "RETRO Act" allows for a credit for hybrid conversion of motor vehicles under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The credit is determined based on the cost of converting a vehicle to a qualified hybrid motor vehicle, up to a certain limit. The RETRO Act provides a tax credit for converting vehicles to qualified hybrid motor vehicles based on gross vehicle weight, with varying credit amounts based on weight categories. The RETRO Act offers a tax credit for converting vehicles to qualified hybrid motor vehicles based on weight categories and achieving minimum fuel consumption reduction. The RETRO Act offers tax credits for converting vehicles to qualified hybrid motor vehicles based on weight categories and achieving minimum fuel consumption reduction. The minimum required reduction percentages vary based on the type of vehicle and its weight. The RETRO Act provides tax credits for converting vehicles to qualified hybrid motor vehicles based on weight categories and achieving minimum fuel consumption reduction. The credit is not allowed if a similar credit has been claimed in a previous taxable year. There is a limitation on the number of hybrid conversions eligible for the credit. The RETRO Act provides tax credits for converting vehicles to qualified hybrid motor vehicles based on weight categories. The applicable credit amounts vary depending on the gross vehicle weight, ranging from $100,000 for vehicles not exceeding 8,500 pounds to $10,000 for vehicles exceeding 26,000 pounds. The credit is subject to termination for conversions made after five years from the enactment of the RETRO Act. Additionally, the credit is treated as part of the Alternative Motor Vehicle Credit under section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The RETRO Act provides tax credits for converting vehicles to qualified hybrid motor vehicles based on weight categories. The credit is subject to termination for conversions made after five years from the enactment of the RETRO Act. Amendments include no recapture for vehicles converted to qualified hybrid motor vehicles and denial of double benefit for certain motor vehicles. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after the date of the enactment of this Act. Unobligated federal funds are rescinded to offset the loss in revenues caused by the amendments. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget determines the amount and implementation of the rescission. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will submit a report to identify unobligated funds for rescission, excluding funds for the Department of Veterans Affairs, Department of Defense, and disaster relief.
